description: The Distribution Load Relief Program (DLRP) provides network-level support through load relief when the next contingency on the Con Edison system would result in a Condition Yellow (an outage to more than 15,000 customers or electric distribution equipment loaded above emergency ratings) or a voltage reduction of five percent or greater has been ordered. Participants receive notification two hours or less before events and are compensated with capacity payments and performance payments for reducing load during distribution system contingencies.

utilities: Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (Con Edison)
service_territories: Con Edison electric service territory (New York City and Westchester County)
82 distribution networks throughout service territory (as of 2025)
Networks separated into Tier 1 and Tier 2 based on demand response priority

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Commercial and industrial facilities of all sizes may participate. Participants enrolling with a single account must provide a minimum of 50 kW of load reduction. Aggregators must enroll a minimum of 50 total kW across all enrolled customers (aggregate requirement, not per network).

resource_types: battery energy storage (with restrictions - see additional_requirements)
additional_requirements: Communicating interval meter required for all Rider T participants
Con Edison may provide interval meter at no cost for customers with less than 500 kW electric demand
Battery storage systems with active Program Agreement in Con Edison's Non-Wires Solutions (NWS) energy storage incentive programs are NOT eligible for DLRP due to response conflicts
Customers enrolling in both CSRP and DLRP must use the same aggregator
Aggregators must have sales agreements explicitly naming the Con Edison DLRP program
All DR aggregators required to sign Data Security Agreement (DSA) per UBP DERS case 15-M-0180

notification_details: DLRP Contingency Events: At least 2 hours advance notice
DLRP Immediate Events: Less than 2 hours advance notice
Notification sent when contingency affecting specific network area occurs
Test events called with similar notification procedures

capacity_rate.notes: Electrical networks are separated into Tier 1 and Tier 2. Tier 2 networks are considered higher priority for demand response and compensated at higher incentive rate. For 2025, two new networks were categorized as Tier 2. Network tier assignments determine capacity payment rate.

performance_rate.notes: Performance payment of $1.00/kWh applies to energy reduced during all DLRP events (both Contingency and Immediate Events). Voluntary customers can enroll after enrollment deadlines and receive $3.00/kWh performance payment rate during events.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No monetary penalties for non-performance. However, non-performance in one event may negatively impact overall payments. Primary consequence is loss of opportunity to receive demand response payments for that event.

payment_details: Capacity (Reservation) payments made monthly during capability period (May-September)
Performance (Energy) payments calculated based on actual load reduction verified against Customer Baseline Load (CBL)
Payments made to aggregators who then compensate enrolled customers per contract terms
Direct enrollees receive payments directly from Con Edison

seasons.notes: Events can be called any time during capability period except between 12:00 AM (midnight) and 8:00 AM. DLRP can be called on weekdays, weekends, and federal holidays throughout the capability period.

call_windows.notes: Load Relief Period: 08:00 to 24:00 (midnight). Events generally called during this window based on network contingency needs.
Events may be activated between midnight and 8:00 AM on voluntary basis. Standard events cannot be called during this window.

event_trigger_conditions: One contingency away from Condition Yellow
Active voltage reduction by network (5% or greater ordered)
Condition Yellow declared: next contingency (excluding substation breaker failure) would result in outage to more than 15,000 customers
Condition Yellow declared: next contingency would load electric distribution equipment above emergency ratings

historical_event_frequency.notes: 3% decrease in enrolled capacity from 2023, but 19% increase in customer count. Test event performance improved from 72% to 80%.

event_parameters.notes: Event frequency has increased from 8 days in 2022 to 14 days in 2024. Maximum number of times any single network was called increased from 2 events in 2022 to 5 events in 2024. One test event is called each capability period.

enrollment_period.notes: Customers can enroll at any point throughout the year, but will only earn rewards during the capability period (May 1 - September 30). Specific enrollment deadline for May 2025 capability period not specified in public documentation. Voluntary customers can enroll after enrollment deadlines. Contact demandresponse@coned.com for current enrollment deadlines and application forms.

baseline_methodology.day_selection_method: Reverse order selection of 10 days for CBL window
day_elimination_criteria: Days when Con Edison declared DLRP events are eliminated from CBL development
Low usage days eliminated if average daily event period usage is less than 25% of average event period usage
baseline_calculation_steps: Step 1: Select 10-day CBL window using reverse order selection
Step 2: Eliminate DLRP event days and low usage days (< 25% of average event period usage)
Step 3: Identify 5 days from the 10-day CBL window to develop CBL values for each hour
Step 4: Establish Average Day CBL from selected 5 days
Step 5: Calculate Event Final Adjustment Factor and apply to each hourly value of Average Day CBL
baseline_methodology.weather_adjustment_method: For weather-sensitive verification method: CBL adjusted upward or downward based on actual usage in the two hours prior to event notification
baseline_methodology.adjustment_factor: Event Final Adjustment Factor calculated and applied to hourly CBL values
baseline_methodology.performance_calculation: Actual load levels compared to CBL to verify whether participants provided contracted kW of load reduction. Performance factor calculated as delivered reduction divided by pledged reduction.

testing_requirements.test_frequency: One 2-hour test event called during each seasonal capability period
testing_requirements.test_notification: Notification provided similar to actual event (2 hours or less advance notice)
testing_requirements.test_compensation: Test event participation counts toward program performance metrics
performance_metrics: Test event performance factor calculated as actual reduction divided by pledged reduction
2024 test event: 80% average performance factor (8 percentage point improvement)

special_attributes: Network-specific program - events called by individual distribution network based on local contingency needs
Can be called on weekends and federal holidays throughout capability period
Concurrent participation allowed with CSRP (Commercial System Relief Program) if using same aggregator
Two-tier payment structure based on network priority classification
Part of Con Edison's Smart Usage Rewards suite of demand response programs
Supports distribution system reliability and defers network infrastructure upgrades

program_evolution.change_description: Two new networks categorized as Tier 2. Randall's Island network merged with West Bronx network, resulting in 82 total networks throughout service territory. Several networks received new call window assignments. New NYCRR Part 222 regulations become effective May 1, 2025.

Program saw 19% increase in enrolled customers (38,649 total) but 3% decrease in enrolled capacity (472.51 MW). Event frequency increased to 14 event days with maximum of 5 calls to any single network. Test event performance improved to 80%.
Program enrolled 488 MW capacity with 991.6 MW pledged, delivering 766.6 MW in reductions. 11 event days occurred with maximum of 3 calls to any single network. Test event performance was 72%.
8 event days occurred with maximum of 2 calls to any single network.

historical_events.notes: 14 event days in 2024, with maximum of 5 events called for any single network. 1 test event included. Total enrolled: 38,649 customers with 472.51 MW capacity, delivering 374.05 MW in reductions.
11 event days in 2023, with maximum of 3 events called for any single network. 1 test event included. Total enrolled: 488 MW capacity pledged, with 991.6 MW enrolled and 766.6 MW delivered.
8 event days in 2022, with maximum of 2 events called for any single network. 1 test event included.

key_differences: Trigger Mechanism: CSRP is forecast-based (92% of summer peak demand forecast or temperature triggers), called day-ahead. DLRP is contingency-based (distribution system emergencies), called with 0-2 hours notice.
Response Speed: CSRP provides 21 hours advance notice for planned events. DLRP provides 0-2 hours notice (much faster response required).

Event Windows: CSRP events are weekdays only 11 AM-11 PM with 4-hour duration in fixed windows. DLRP events can occur 8 AM-midnight any day of week (including weekends/holidays) with flexible duration.
Payment Rates: CSRP pays $6-18/kW-month (location-based) plus $1/kWh. DLRP pays $18-25/kW-month (tier-based) plus $1/kWh. DLRP has higher capacity payments.

Geographic Granularity: CSRP uses borough-based tiers (Brooklyn/Bronx/Manhattan/Queens = $18/kW-month, Staten Island/Westchester = $6/kW-month). DLRP uses 82 individual network tiers (Tier 1 = $18/kW-month, Tier 2 = $25/kW-month).
Event Predictability: CSRP events are more predictable (weather/demand forecasting). DLRP events are less predictable (distribution contingencies).
Concurrent Participation: Can participate in both CSRP and DLRP simultaneously if using same aggregator.
System Level: CSRP addresses transmission-level system peaks. DLRP addresses distribution-level network constraints.
Event Frequency: CSRP typically 5-10 planned events per summer. DLRP has increased from 8 days (2022) to 14 days (2024) but varies by network.
Value Proposition: CSRP provides predictable revenue with day-ahead planning. DLRP provides higher payments but requires faster response to unpredictable contingencies.
csrp_comparison.stacking_opportunities: YES - Customers can enroll in both CSRP and DLRP simultaneously. Must use same aggregator for both programs. CSRP handles predictable summer peaks with advance notice; DLRP handles local distribution emergencies with short notice. Total potential capacity payments: $6-18/kW-month (CSRP) + $18-25/kW-month (DLRP) = $24-43/kW-month in best-case Tier 2 locations.

term_auto_dlm_comparison.program_name: Term Dynamic Load Management and Auto Dynamic Load Management
key_differences: Contract Structure: Term-DLM and Auto-DLM offer 3-5 year fixed-price contracts. DLRP is annual tariff-based enrollment with potential rate changes each year.
Procurement Method: Term/Auto-DLM use competitive pay-as-bid procurement (rates determined by bidding). DLRP uses fixed tariff rates published by Con Edison ($18-25/kW-month).
Revenue Certainty: Term/Auto-DLM provide multi-year revenue certainty for financing. DLRP has annual rate uncertainty.
Response Times: Term-DLM provides 21 hours notice (similar to CSRP). Auto-DLM provides 10 minutes notice (faster than DLRP's 0-2 hours). DLRP provides 0-2 hours notice.
Availability Windows: Term-DLM weekdays only, 4-hour windows (11 AM-11 PM). Auto-DLM 6 AM-midnight, 7 days/week. DLRP 8 AM-midnight, 7 days/week.
Event Triggers: Term-DLM is forecast-based (similar to CSRP). Auto-DLM is rapid-response contingency-based. DLRP is distribution network contingency-based.
Program Valuation: Term-DLM valued as CSRP equivalent. Auto-DLM valued as CSRP + DLRP combined capabilities. DLRP is standalone distribution program.
Target Resources: Term/Auto-DLM specifically designed to incentivize battery energy storage with long-term contracts. DLRP accepts all demand response resources.
Geographic Scope: Term/Auto-DLM use same network tier structure. DLRP uses 82 network-specific call zones with 2 payment tiers.
Enrollment Process: Term/Auto-DLM require competitive bid submission by February deadline. DLRP allows rolling enrollment throughout year.
term_auto_dlm_comparison.strategic_choice: Term/Auto-DLM vs DLRP decision depends on asset financing needs and risk tolerance. Choose Term/Auto-DLM for: (1) New battery projects requiring long-term revenue certainty for financing, (2) Sophisticated operators comfortable with competitive bidding, (3) Assets optimized for either day-ahead scheduling (Term-DLM) or ultra-fast response (Auto-DLM 10-min). Choose DLRP for: (1) Flexible annual participation without long-term commitments, (2) Known fixed tariff rates without bidding uncertainty, (3) Ability to stack with CSRP for dual revenue streams, (4) Network-specific optimization (82 networks provide geographic granularity). Note: Battery operators can participate in Term-DLM OR CSRP (not both), and Auto-DLM OR DLRP (not both), but can combine one from each category.

battery_suitability.comparison_to_csrp: DLRP is MORE suitable than CSRP for batteries optimized for fast response and local distribution support. DLRP pays HIGHER capacity rates ($18-25/kW-month vs CSRP's $6-18/kW-month) and offers BETTER stacking potential (can combine with CSRP). However, CSRP's 21-hour advance notice is EASIER to optimize than DLRP's 0-2 hour notice. For maximum revenue, sophisticated battery operators should enroll in BOTH programs using same aggregator.
battery_suitability.comparison_to_term_auto_dlm: DLRP provides FLEXIBILITY (annual enrollment, no long-term commitment) while Term/Auto-DLM provide REVENUE CERTAINTY (3-5 year contracts). For new battery projects requiring financing, Term/Auto-DLM's long-term contracts are SUPERIOR. For existing batteries with flexible operation, DLRP's known tariff rates and CSRP stacking potential are ADVANTAGEOUS. Auto-DLM's 10-minute response competes directly with DLRP's 0-2 hour response but requires 3-5 year commitment.
key_advantages_for_batteries: Higher capacity payments than CSRP: $18-25/kW-month vs $6-18/kW-month
Can stack with CSRP for combined capacity payments up to $43/kW-month (Tier 2 DLRP + Tier 2 CSRP)
7-day availability (including weekends) matches battery's always-available capability
0-2 hour response time is achievable for battery energy storage systems
Network-specific calls (82 networks) allow geographic optimization
No penalties for non-performance (only lost opportunity cost)
15-minute interval metering matches typical battery dispatch granularity
Event frequency increasing (8 days in 2022 to 14 days in 2024) shows growing program value
Summer-only season (May-Sept) aligns with peak arbitrage opportunities
key_challenges_for_batteries: CRITICAL RESTRICTION: Batteries with active Non-Wires Solutions (NWS) program agreements are NOT ELIGIBLE for DLRP
Short 0-2 hour notice requires fast automated dispatch - less time for arbitrage optimization
Event duration and timing unpredictable (distribution contingencies)
Must use same aggregator if participating in both CSRP and DLRP
Customer Baseline Load (CBL) methodology complex - may be challenging for batteries without historical load profile
Cannot combine with Auto-DLM program (mutually exclusive rapid-response programs)
Events triggered by distribution contingencies are harder to forecast than CSRP's demand-based events

scenario_1_tier_2_network_dlrp_only.description: 1 MW / 4 MWh battery in Tier 2 network (Brooklyn/Bronx/Manhattan/Queens), DLRP only
scenario_1_tier_2_network_dlrp_only.notes: Conservative estimate using 10 events (between 2022's 8 days and 2024's 14 days) and 3-hour average duration

scenario_2_tier_2_network_csrp_plus_dlrp.description: 1 MW / 4 MWh battery in Tier 2 locations (both programs), CSRP + DLRP stack
scenario_2_tier_2_network_csrp_plus_dlrp.notes: BEST CASE for demand response stacking. Requires same aggregator and automated dispatch system to respond to both programs without conflicts. Performance payments assume no overlapping events.

scenario_3_tier_1_network_dlrp_only.description: 1 MW / 4 MWh battery in Tier 1 network (Staten Island/Westchester/other networks), DLRP only
scenario_3_tier_1_network_dlrp_only.notes: Tier 1 networks may have fewer events than Tier 2 (lower priority), using conservative 8 events estimate

battery_suitability.optimal_battery_configuration: DLRP strongly favors batteries with: (1) Fast automated dispatch systems capable of 0-2 hour response, (2) Duration flexibility (events can be short or long), (3) Location in Tier 2 networks for $25/kW-month capacity payments, (4) Aggregator relationship that can manage both CSRP and DLRP simultaneously, (5) No existing Non-Wires Solutions program commitments. Ideal configuration: 1-4 hour duration BESS in high-constraint Tier 2 network (Brooklyn/Bronx/Manhattan/Queens) with dual CSRP+DLRP enrollment through sophisticated aggregator.
battery_suitability.nws_program_conflict: CRITICAL EXCLUSION: Batteries participating in Con Edison's Non-Wires Solutions (NWS) energy storage incentive programs CANNOT participate in DLRP due to response conflicts. NWS programs provide upfront capital incentives for battery deployment in specific constrained networks but impose operational restrictions. Battery operators must choose: (1) NWS upfront capital incentive + restricted operation, OR (2) DLRP ongoing demand response revenue + operational flexibility. This is a strategic decision during project planning phase and cannot be changed once NWS Program Agreement is signed.

data_sources.source_name: Con Edison Smart Usage Rewards - DLRP Program Page
Con Edison Demand Response (Rider T) Program Guidelines - 2025 Capability Period
Con Edison Customer Baseline Load Procedure
Con Edison Networks and Tiers Document
NYISO DLRP Con Edison Tariff Information

integration_metadata.research_quality_notes: Comprehensive program information verified from multiple official Con Edison sources. Payment rates clearly documented. Historical event data available for 2022-2024. Detailed comparison with CSRP and Term/Auto-DLM programs completed. Battery suitability analysis includes financial modeling for multiple scenarios. All data verified - NO INVENTED DATA. Minor information gaps: specific enrollment deadlines require direct contact with Con Edison; detailed network tier assignments require Networks and Tiers PDF (attempted but PDF extraction limited); exact event durations not specified in public docs.
integration_metadata.notes: DLRP is fourth Con Edison demand response program researched (after CSRP in Batch 8, Term/Auto-DLM in Batch 10, LMIP reference). Known as excellent distribution-constrained area program with higher capacity payments than CSRP. Key differentiators: (1) Faster response requirements (0-2 hours vs CSRP's 21 hours), (2) Higher capacity payments ($18-25/kW-month vs CSRP's $6-18/kW-month), (3) Distribution network-specific operation (82 networks vs borough-level tiers), (4) Can stack with CSRP for maximum revenue. Battery suitability excellent for fast-responding systems in Tier 2 networks, with critical restriction on NWS program conflicts. Program event frequency increasing over time (8 days 2022 → 14 days 2024) indicating growing importance to grid reliability.

additional_program_details.program_administrator: Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
additional_program_details.tariff_reference: Rider T, beginning on Leaf 268 of Con Edison electric tariff
related_programs: Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) - can participate concurrently with DLRP using same aggregator
Term Dynamic Load Management (Term-DLM) - long-term contract alternative to CSRP, mutually exclusive with CSRP
Auto Dynamic Load Management (Auto-DLM) - long-term contract alternative to DLRP, mutually exclusive with DLRP
Smart Usage Rewards suite - umbrella program including multiple demand response options
Non-Wires Solutions (NWS) Energy Storage Incentive - mutually exclusive with DLRP for battery storage
regulatory_framework: New York Public Service Commission oversight
UBP DERS (Uniform Business Practices for Distributed Energy Resource Suppliers) case 15-M-0180
metering_and_telemetry: Communicating interval meter required for all Rider T participants
Con Edison may provide interval meter at no cost for customers < 500 kW demand
Data used for CBL calculation and performance verification
aggregator_requirements: Minimum 50 kW total enrollment across all customers (aggregate)
Sales agreements must explicitly name Con Edison DLRP program
Data Security Agreement (DSA) required per UBP DERS
Must submit enrollment information to Con Edison prior to summer capability period
If customer enrolls in both CSRP and DLRP, must use same aggregator for both programs
additional_program_details.direct_enrollment_notes: Individual customers can enroll directly without aggregator if they can pledge ≥50 kW load reduction. Email demandresponse@coned.com for application forms.
